poem:
**Til's Endurance**

In Til, a thousand-year breath,   
night's silence shatters.  
Bare feet trace the old earth's tremor;  
rivers unbraid, stone and mud speak  
in tongues of torrent.   
The mountain leans in like an elder  
telling an urgent tale,   
as villagers stand—still,  
their future hung  
on a whisper of water.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "This Nepal village has survived for 1,000 years. Now recurring floods threaten its future On the night of 15 May this year, the usual quiet of the Himalayan village of Til in the far north-west of Nepal was broken by a strange rumbling. Pemba Thundup came out of his house, barefoot, to see a deluge of earth, water and rocks coming down the mountainside towards the flat-roofed mud houses. The whole village was soon awake". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
